where did we come from how did we get
here are we alone in the universe
these are the kinds of big questions

our day-to-day jobs and that's one of
the reasons that being an astrophysicist
is such a cool job we get to think about
these huge questions that are bigger
than just science questions these are
questions that human beings have been

that get to the heart of why we as human
beings are driven to discover and to
explore our surroundings so one of those
big questions is where do we come from
if people often ask me where did how did
I get to where I am at NASA today and
it's actually quite a simple story I
grew up in a small rural farming town in
Arkansas the sky was stunningly
beautiful and those stars call my name
they caused me to ask questions like how
many stars are there
what are they like what are they made of
and what's beyond what I can see
so as an astronomer one of our primary
tools our telescopes and as an
astronomer I've been able to use
telescopes all across the world it's one
of the good perks of being an astronomer
is a lot of the world's biggest
telescopes are in beautiful places like
Hawaii and Chile and I've been to these
telescopes to observe which is awesome
but even on the world's highest
mountaintops they're still atmosphere
and what astronomers need to do is get
above the atmosphere and so one of the
great things we've been able to do as
human beings is patella scopes into
space and of course that's one of the
primary jobs that NASA does this year
all across the world people are
celebrating the launch of the Hubble
Space Telescope 25 years ago how many of
you in the room are younger than 25 a
lot of you so think about that Hubble
has been in space for yeren
our lives that's pretty remarkable right
and for the past quarter-century Hubble
has been changing the way that we as
scientists think about the universe it
has literally fundamentally changed the
way that we understand how the universe
works and that's one of the great things
about being an astronomer is being able
to learn about how the universe works
and in addition to the awesome science
the Hubble has given us Hubble has given
us stunning imagery the infamous Eagle
Nebula shown here better known as the
pillars of creation has shown us how
beautiful star formation is so we know
that stars are born inside dust pillars
like this inside these large pillars of
dust baby stars are being formed inside
dusty cocoons and many of these little
stars have planets orbiting them around
them as well
so after stars live out their lives they
shine forth in these brilliant star
clusters this star cluster here contains
some of the hottest brightest biggest
stars that we know of as astronomers and
by studying images like this in addition
to being beautiful we're able to learn
about how processes in the universe work
so these paths two images that I've just

within our own Milky Way galaxy so
relatively nearby at a cosmic sense so
our Milky Way galaxy contains a couple
of hundred billion stars that's a lot
right Milky Way is pretty big if you

would take about a hundred thousand

all probably know Milky Way is not our

so the beauty of this image lies in what

ultra-deep field in this image Hubble
stared at one tiny piece of sky for many
many days that's like looking at the

if you held out your pinky finger you

sky it's a little bitty piece of sky and
in this tiny patch of sky Hubble sees

that you're seeing there is an
individual galaxy filled with billions
of stars
so what Hubble has given us is the size

other galaxies the universe is vast and
it's filled with beautiful mysterious

it's obvious the universe is filled with

detectors but you can only see a teeny

that light that's redder than your eyes
can see is called infrared light and so
my friend and colleague laura has joined

great thing about infrared light and how

is that some of the biggest questions in

once it gets out into space and then
we'll launch it in 2018 on a rocket now
this telescope is so big it's bigger

really cool engineering behind this

gov so James Webb Space Telescope
nasa.gov
so this telescope we're building to
answer the biggest questions in
astronomy with this telescope we will be

very first galaxies that were born after

more about how galaxies formed and

born and they will also learn about

started thinking about how to build this

we know of thousands of exoplanets that

distr in the last few years has really

fact now we know that planets are common
when I was a kid we didn't even know of
any other exoplanets but now we know
that if you go outside at night and

new discovery and this telescope is
gonna allow us to study the atmospheres

that might mean with this planet we
might discover a water world we're gonna
learn about these exoplanets that are
out there in much greater detail with

the telescope to answer these very

there are undoubtedly things out there

the promise of hundreds of billions of
